description: From Middle English inklen, inclen (“to give an inkling of, hint at, mention, utter in an undertone”), derived from inke (“apprehension, misgiving”), from Old English inca (“doubt, suspicion”), from Proto-West Germanic *inkō, from Proto-Germanic *inkô (“ache, regret”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁eng- (“illness”). Cognate with Old Frisian jinc (“angered”), Old Norse ekki (“pain, grief”), Norwegian ekkje (“lack, pity”).

verbs.description: inkle (third-person singular simple present inkles, present participle inkling, simple past and past participle inkled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To have a hint or inkling of; divine.

description: Apparently from earlier *ingle, perhaps from an incorrect division of lingle, lingel.

entries.meaning: Narrow linen tape, used for trimmings or to make shoelaces
